identified-content.classifier: Top/News/U.S./U.S. States, Territories and Possessions/New York

block.p: Hundreds of people poured into two neighborhoods in Queens and Brooklyn last night as participants in yesterday afternoon's Dominican Day Parade in Manhattan continued their celebrations, the police said.

Five people were arrested for disorderly conduct in Corona, Queens, as about 200 police officers filled the area near 100th Street and 37th Avenue, said Doram Tamari, a police spokesman. One man was arrested for throwing a bottle at a police officer, who was struck in the arm, said Tom Kelly, deputy commissioner of public information.

Hundreds of people poured into two neighborhoods in Queens and Brooklyn last night as participants in yesterday afternoon's Dominican Day Parade in Manhattan continued their celebrations, the police said.

Five people were arrested for disorderly conduct in Corona, Queens, as about 200 police officers filled the area near 100th Street and 37th Avenue, said Doram Tamari, a police spokesman. One man was arrested for throwing a bottle at a police officer, who was struck in the arm, said Tom Kelly, deputy commissioner of public information.

Commissioner Kelly said the disorder started when a fight broke out among the revelers, and the police intervened. About 200 unruly people, out of a crowd of more than 1,000, had dispersed by 11:30 P.M., the police said.
"Everyone was having a good time," said Jose Perales, 21, who works in a pool hall in Corona. "Nobody was throwing bottles. We started throwing bottles when they started hitting everybody."
In Manhattan yesterday afternoon, the festivities centered around a parade on the Avenue of Americas.
Officers were also called to Williamsburg, Brooklyn, where the police reported an unruly crowd. No arrests were reported.
